learnItems.name: Activity Change
learnItems.question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity?
learnItems.explanation: Addition of a bulky group at N1 prevents binding to the BZR; methyl group is preferred

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Activity Change
learnItems.question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity?
learnItems.explanation: Addition of Cl to position 2 reduces aromatic hydroxylation (phase one P450 metabolism) and increases half-life

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which of these 3 compounds would be the best benzodiazepine for use as a hypnotic?
learnItems.explanation: It already has the hydroxyl handle (position 3) so it is quickly metabolized to an inactive metabolite by conjugation; thus it has a short elimination half-life, which is ideal for hypnotics

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which of these 3 compounds would be the best benzodiazepine for use as an anxiolytic?
learnItems.explanation: The compound is slowly absorbed because it has a carboxylic acid that must be cleaved first (like a prodrug) and it is metabolized to an active metabolite; thus it has a long elimination half-life (40-50 hr), which is ideal for anxiolytics

sections.title: Ring A
sections.content: Pi-Pi stacking with BZR

sections.title: C7
sections.content: EWG increases activity

sections.title: Ring B
sections.content: H-bond acceptor (O, N, S) or N-heterocycle required 1,2 annelation (N-heterocycle) increases affinity for BZR

sections.title: N1
sections.content: methyl group preferred; bulky group decreases activity because it prevents binding to BZR

sections.title: C3
sections.content: OH group eliminates first pass metabolism as the hydroxyl acts as a “handle” for conjugation.

sections.title: Ring C
sections.content: Hydrophobic interaction with BZR

sections.title: C4
sections.content: Steric repulsion occurs with para substituent

sections.title: C2
sections.content: F or Cl substitution reduces aromatic hydroxylation and improves half-life

sections.title: Absorption
sections.content: When taken orally, most BZD show rapid and complete absorption from GI tract

sections.title: Distribution
sections.content: -Increase lipophilicity = Increase rate of CNS distribution. -Cross BBB by passive diffusion.

sections.title: Metabolism
sections.content: -Do NOT induce metabolism of other drugs. -Liver metabolized to active compounds (except lorazepam)

sections.title: Excretion
sections.content: By kidneys

sections.title: Duration of Action
sections.content: [Short Acting]: 1.5-5 hours, Not converted into active intermediates. [Intermediate Acting]: 8-20 hours. [Long Acting]: 30-60 hours, Converted into active intermediates.

sections.title: Mechanism of Action
sections.content: -Potentiates GABA by binding to allosteric site on receptor. Increase the frequency of Cl- channel opening. -Enhancement of GABA activity slows nerve impulses throughout the body, GABA produces calming effect in the brain.

sections.title: Pharmacological Action
sections.content: -Sedation (decrease latency and REM). -Reduction in muscle tone. -Tolerance develops after 1-2 weeks of use. -Reduction in anxiety.

sections.title: Side-Effects
sections.content: Drowsiness, Fatigue, Amnesia, Ataxia

sections.title: Uses
sections.content: Anti-Epileptic (diazepam, lorazepam), Insomnia (temazepam, triazolam), Anti-anxiety (diazepam, lorazepam), Muscle spasms (diazepam), Anesthesia (diazepam, lorazepam, midazolam). *Duration of Action determines therapeutic use.

sections.title: Notes
sections.content: -Duration of action and elimination half life are NOT the same. -BZD increase frequency of Cl- channel opening. -GABA must be present for BZD to have effect. -Flumazenil = BZD receptor antagonist for treatment of acute overdose.

colorLocationAssociations.description: Barbiturates can undergo enol-keto tautomerization, which gives them near neutral pkas (7.4). Less than 50% gets ionized, so good balance of solubility and CNS penetration.
Without any substitution at position 5, the acidic hydrogen gets deprotonated. Resonance stabilization leads to lower pka (4) and 99% ionization occurs, so unable to penetrate the CNS.

sections.title: N1
sections.content: Must be a nitrogen and unsubstitued if N3 is substituted. Carbon group substitution will increase lipophilicity and more rapid onset of action.

sections.title: N3
sections.content: Must be a nitrogen and unsubstituted if N1 is substituted. Carbon group substitution will increase lipophilicity and more rapid onset of action.

sections.title: C2
sections.content: Changing C=O → C=S increases lipophilicity and more rapid onset of action

sections.title: C4 & C6
sections.content: Must contain C=O

sections.title: R1 & R2
sections.content: bulky carbon groups increases lipophilicity and more rapid onset of action

sections.title: C5
sections.content: Must be disubstituted alkyl groups to be active in the CNS

sections.title: Absorption
sections.content: IV and Oral

sections.title: Distribution
sections.content: Increases lipid solubility = quicker entry into CNS. Barbiturates redistribute from brain to muscles and fat tissue.

sections.title: Metabolism
sections.content: Metabolized in the liver

sections.title: Excretion
sections.content: Excreted in urine by kidney

sections.title: MOA Explanation
sections.content: Prolong GABA activity. Increase duration of Cl- channel opening. Also blocks the AMPA- receptor which is sensitive to glutamate, the excitatory transmitter. Blocking this action increases the duration of receptor response to GABA and extends the depressed condition of the cell.

sections.title: Pharmacological Action
sections.content: [CNS Depression]: Sedation at low doses. Hypnosis followed by anesthesia at high doses. [Respiratory Depression]: Suppress hypoxic and chemoreceptor response to C02 -> Can lead to death.

sections.title: Side-Effects
sections.content: Alcohol like symptoms: Impaired motor control (ataxia), dizziness, slower breathing and heart rate. Enzyme induction (CYP450). Potential for addiction.

sections.title: Uses
sections.content: NOT used as sedative or hypnotic. Anesthetic: Ultra short acting (thiopental). Anti-seizure: Long acting (phenobarbital).

sections.title: Notes
sections.content: Physical dependence, Severe withdrawal symptoms, low toxicity threshold, tolerance develops.

learnItems.title: Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Trissa is 30-year old female suffering from anxiety and insomnia. What one compound would be best to treat both her anxiety and insomnia?
learnItems.explanation: Benzodiazepine (Compound 2)

learnItems.title: Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Sakiya is 24-year old female suffering from anxiety and insomnia. Sakiya’s boyfriend takes one of these hypnotics for insomnia and it helps keep him asleep with no hangover effects in the morning. LM decides to take one of his pills, but in the morning she is still sleepy. Which of these compounds did she take and why is she still experiencing effects in the morning?
learnItems.explanation: Zolpidem (Compound 1); women metabolize slower

learnItems.title: Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Lance is 27-year old female suffering from anxiety and insomnia. Unfortunately, Lance has had abuse disorders in the past. Which of these compounds would be safest to use to treat her insomnia?
learnItems.explanation: Ramelteon (Compound 3); not a scheduled drug

sections.title: Key Characteristics
sections.content: Women metabolize slower. Used to treat insomnia.

sections.title: Key Pharmacokinetic
sections.content: Rapidly absorbed in GI tract. Rapid onset and short elimination T1/2 (2-3 hours). Metabolism: Hepatic oxidation by CYP450.

sections.title: Action/Effect
sections.content: Selective for GABA-A alpha-1 subunit. Sedative.

sections.title: Side Effects
sections.content: Nightmares, agitation, headache, GI upset, dizziness, drowsiness.

sections.title: Key Characteristics
sections.content: Used to treat insomnia.

sections.title: Key Pharmacokinetic
sections.content: Fewer residual effect on psychomotor and cognitive functions. Rapid elimination and T1/2 of 1 hour = Good to tak in the middle of night. Metabolism: CYP450.

sections.title: Action/Effect
sections.content: Selective for GABA-A alpha-1 subunit. Sedative.

sections.title: Side Effects
sections.content: Dizziness, Drowsiness, Lack of coordination.

sections.title: Key Characteristics
sections.content: Longest T1/2. Used for chronic insomnia.

sections.title: Key Pharmacokinetic
sections.content: Elimination half life ~6 hours. Metabolism: oxidation and demethylation via CYP450. Rapidly absorbed.

sections.title: Action/Effect
sections.content: Acts at several GABA-A subunits, including alpha-1 and alpha-2 subunit. Sedative and Anxiolytic.

sections.title: Side Effects
sections.content: Anxiety, dry mount, headache, peripheral edema, somnolence, unpleasant taste.

learnItems.title: Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Henry is 45-year old male who has recently been suffering from  what is believed to be absence seizures. Which compound should he be prescribed?
learnItems.explanation: Ethosuximide (Compound 2); best used for absence seizures

learnItems.title: Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Amir is 48-year old male who has recently been suffering from what is believed to be absence seizures. Unfortunately, ethosuximide was not effective, and it is decided that Amir needs a medication for partial seizures instead. Amir also is taking several other medications. Which compound should he take?
learnItems.explanation: : Lamotrigine (Compound 3); not metabolized by CYP and does not induce CYP, which could interfere with other medications

sections.title: Common toxicities of many antiepileptic drugs
Pathophysiology of a seizure
sections.content: Finite episodes of brain dysfunction resulting from abnormal repetitive discharge of cerebral neurons.

sections.title: Common toxicities of many antiepileptic drugs
sections.content: Sedation, Rashes, Teratogenicity, Cerebellar: Ataxia & Nystagmus, CYP450 Interactions.

sections.title: Notes
sections.content: Anti-epileptics do not block ALL action potentials - blocking all would cause death.

sections.title: Decrease Excitatory Activity
sections.content: *Works at Glutamatergic synapse. 1. Block NA+ Channels. 2. Block Ca+ Channels. 3. Activate K+ Channels. 4. Block NMDA-Receptor. 5. Block NMDA-Receptor. 6. Bind to Synaptic Vesicle Proteins.

sections.title: Increase Inhibitory Activity
sections.content: *Works at GABAergic synapse. 1. Block GABA Transporter (More GABA in synapse). 2. Block GABA Transaminase (Block metabolism of GABA). 3. Increase potency of GABA @ GABA-A Receptor.

sections.title: Target/MOA
sections.content: Decrease Ca+ Channel Activity

sections.title: Neurotransmitter
sections.content: Glutamate (Decrease excitatory activity)

sections.title: Drugs
sections.content: Phenobarbital, Ethosuximide, Valproic Aid, Gabapentin, Pregabalin

sections.title: Target/MOA
sections.content: Decrease Na+ Channel Activity

sections.title: Neurotransmitter
sections.content: Glutamate (Decrease excitatory activity)

sections.title: Drugs
sections.content: Phenytoin, Carbamazepine, Valproic Acid, Lamotrigine, Topiramate

sections.title: Target/MOA
sections.content: Binds to synaptic vesicle protein to reduce presynaptic NT release

sections.title: Neurotransmitter
sections.content: Glutamate (Decrease excitatory activity)

sections.title: Drugs

sections.title: Target/MOA

sections.title: Neurotransmitter

sections.title: Drugs
sections.content: Phenobarbital, Diazepam, Lorazepam

sections.title: Target/MOA
sections.content: Inhibition of GABA metabolism

sections.title: Neurotransmitter

sections.title: Drugs
sections.content: Valproic Acid

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem

learnItems.question: Which of these 3 antidepressants has major side effects as GI upset and sexual dysfunction?
learnItems.explanation: Paroxetine is an SRI, which commonly shows these adverse events

learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which of these 3 antidepressants is most selective for SERT?
learnItems.explanation: Sertraline is an SRI, which is selective for SERT. Compound 1 is an NRI and compound 2 is a secondary amine TCA, which is more selective for NET.

sections.content: protonated at physiological pH; pKa 8.7−9.8

sections.title: Electron-withdrawing group:
sections.content: para or meta substitution enhances binding affinity for SERT. -Ortho substitution (except CF3) enhances binding affinity for NET and results in NRI

sections.title: Phenoxy:
sections.content: distinguishes antidepressant and antihistamine activity (derived from diphenhydramine)

sections.title: Basic Nitrogen
sections.content: Protonated at physiological pH; pKa 9.5

sections.title: Chlorine
sections.content: enhances SERT selectivity

sections.title: Explanation
sections.content: Blocks Serotonin Transporter (SERT) on pre-synaptic neuron resulting in increased serotonin in the synapse which is available to bind to post synaptic serotonin receptors.

sections.title: Acute SRI Use
sections.content: 1. Drug blocks 5-HT re-update (SERT) 2. Auto receptor (5-HT1A) activity decreases 3. 5-HT release decreases

sections.title: Chronic SRI Use
sections.content: 1. Auto receptor (5-HT1A) function is lost 2. 5-HT release returns to normal 3. Now serotonin in synapse is greatly increased

sections.title: Side-Effects
sections.content: Nausea & GI symptoms, Sexual effects (decreased libido & sexual dysfunction), Mild restlessness, Mild headaches, Mild Insomnia

sections.title: Uses
sections.content: Depression, OCD, panic disorder, anxiety

sections.title: Notes
sections.content: SRIs compete with metabolism of other drugs, Never use in combo with MAOIs (MAOIs inhibit breakdown of SRIs and could lead to overdose of serotonin in the brain)

colorLocationAssociations.description: Serotonin and Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors do not have any Structure Activity Requirements but these are some helpful structures to be familiar with.
Serotonin and Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors do not have any Structure Activity Requirements but these are some helpful structures to be familiar with.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which of these 3 antidepressants is active at both SERT and NET?
learnItems.explanation: Duloxetine is an SNRI, which is active at SERT and NET. Compound 1 is SRI and Compound 3 is bupropion, which weakly blocks DAT and NET

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which of these 3 antidepressants is considered activating and may raise blood pressure?
learnItems.explanation: Venlafaxine is an SNRI, which is known to be activating

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: Alfred Smith is 80-year old male suffering from depression. He is currently taking paroxetine, but it is not helping. What one compound would you recommend he try next?
learnItems.explanation: Compound 1 is an SRI, which he was currently taking and not helping. Compound 2 is a tertiary amine TCA, which acts as a SNRI and would be helpful, but leads to adverse effects such as sedation and hypotension so not recommended in elderly. Compound 3 (venlafaxine) is best choice as it is SNRI, with few adverse effects.

testItems.question: Venlafaxine and duloxetine are examples of:
SNRI’s have _________ effects such as agitation
(venlafaxine/duloxetine) is more potent than (venlafaxine/duloxetine)
SNRI’s are similar to TCA potency, have (less/more) side effects, and (faster/slower) than SRI alone
_________ has an active metabolite
BONUS: Venlafaxine's active metabolite's name is:

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Activity Change
learnItems.question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity at SERT?
learnItems.explanation: Tertiary→ Secondary amine decreases binding affinity for SERT

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Activity Change
learnItems.question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity at SERT?
learnItems.explanation: Presence of EWG (Cl) enhances binding affinity for SERT

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which of these 3 antidepressants is active at both SERT and NET?
learnItems.explanation: Compound 2, amitriptyline is a tertiary TCA, which is active at SERT and NET. Compound 1 is SRI and Compound 3 is a secondary TCA, only active at NET

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which of these 3 antidepressants causes significant dry mouth, constipation, and sedation?
learnItems.explanation: Compound 1, clomipramine is a tertiary TCA, which is can bind to muscarinic and histamine receptors resulting in off target adverse effects. Compound 2 is a SRI and does not cause these adverse effects. Compound 3 is a mirtazepine and while it can cause sedation, it does not display anticholinergic effects such as dry mouth and constipation.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Predict Metabolite Activity
learnItems.question: Predict whether the metabolites will be active or inactive for the compound products. Would amitriptyline be an ideal antidepressant for the elderly?
learnItems.explanation: Aamitriptyline causes anticholinergic effects, therefore it is not an ideal antidepressant for the elderly.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Predict Metabolite Activity
learnItems.question: Predict whether the metabolites will be active or inactive for the compound products
learnItems.explanation: No explanation for this item.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Predict Metabolite Activity
learnItems.question: Predict whether the metabolites will be active or inactive for the compound product. Is nortriptyline considered an SNRI or NRI?
learnItems.explanation: Nortriptyline is a secondary TCA so it is more selective for NET.

testItems.question: Tertiary TCAs have slightly greater selectivity for blockade of (Norepinephrine/Serotonin) reuptake over (Norepinephrine/Serotonin) reuptake
Secondary TCA’s, such as (Nortriptyline/Amitriptyline) have greater selectivity for blockade of (Norepinephrine/Serotonin)
TCA adverse effects include _____________ effects such as dry eyes and mouth
Onset of action for TCA’s takes 2-3:
Side effects include sexual dysfunction, constipation, and:

sections.title: Linker of 3 carbons
sections.content: Linker of 3 carbons between tricyclic ring system and basic nitrogen. Branching from linker decreases binding affinity for SERT and NET. Unsaturation of linker is tolerated.

sections.title: R→ CH3, tertiary amine
sections.content: R→ CH3, tertiary amine imparts selectivity for SERT

sections.title: R→ H, secondary amine
sections.content: R→ H, secondary amine imparts selectivity for NET

sections.title: R’→ Cl or CN (EWG)
sections.content: R’→ Cl or CN (EWG) enhances binding affinity for SERT

sections.title: R’→ no substitution
sections.content: R’→ no substitution decreases SERT preference

sections.title: Y→ can be C or N
sections.content: Y→ can be C or N

sections.title: Conformationally rigid [6.7.6]-fused ring system
sections.content: Conformationally rigid [6.7.6]-fused ring system - 7 membered ring in the middle is not coplanar; results in twisted shape

sections.title: Explanation
sections.content: Block SERT & NET to inhibit seratonin and norepinephrine reuptake. Block muscarinic, Histamine H1, and Alpha adrenergic receptors

sections.title: Side-Effects
sections.content: [Amitriptyline]: Sedation, Hypotension, Anti-Muscarinic, Weight Gain. [Nortiptyline]: No major side effects.

sections.title: Notes
sections.content: [Amitriptyline]: Can cause extreme CNS depression leading to death if OD. [Nortiptyline]: Selectively blocks NET with much more affinity than SERT.

colorLocationAssociations.description: Circled parts of each structure are helpful to associate with the compounds. There are no SAR Requirements for Atypical Antidepressants
Circled parts of each structure are helpful to associate with the compounds. There are no SAR Requirements for Atypical Antidepressants
Circled parts of each structure are helpful to associate with the compounds. There are no SAR Requirements for Atypical Antidepressants

learnItems.title: Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which of these 3 antidepressants can also be used for smoking cessation?
learnItems.explanation: Bupropion

learnItems.title: Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which of these 3 antidepressants causes sedation by blocking histamine receptors?
learnItems.explanation: Mirtazepine

learnItems.title: Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Compare Compounds
learnItems.question: Which of these 3 antidepressants can result in a hepatotoxic metabolite?
learnItems.explanation: Metabolism of Trazodone

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: Mary Sue is 25-year old male suffering from depression. She complains of feeling tired and gaining weight with her last course of antidepressants. Which compound would you recommend her to try?
learnItems.explanation: Compound 1 (trazodone) can cause sedation. Compound 2 (amitriptyline) can cause weight gain. Compound 3 (bupropion) would be a good alternative for this patient to prevent unwanted adverse effects.

testItems.question: Significant side effect of both trazodone and mirtazepine is:
Trazodone works by blocking the ______ serotonin receptor and being an agonist at the _______ serotonin receptor
Mirtazapine blocks a serotonin receptor and a ________ receptor
Buproprion has a potential for ___________ at high doses
__________ can cause increase appetite and weight gain while ___________ can have the opposite effect
______________ can be used a sleep aid independent of its antidepressant activity

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: None

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: None

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: None

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Blocks SERT and alpha1-adrenergic receptor. Agonist at 5-HT1A on post-synaptic neuron.

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: None

sections.title: Side Effects
sections.content: [Major]: Sedation. [Minor]: GI, Weight Gain.

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Blocks H1 histamine receptor, 5HT2 receptor and alpha2-adrendergic receptor. Agonist at 5HT1A on post synaptic neuron.

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: None

sections.title: Side Effects
sections.content: [Major]: Sedation. [Minor]: Weight Gain

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Blocks DAT and NET resulting in increased dopamine and NE in extracellular space - dopamine acts on reward pathway to improve mood.

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: None

sections.title: Side Effects
sections.content: [Major]: Insomnia, Agitation. [Minor]: Nausea, Dry Mouth

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Blocks SERT and NET resulting in increased levels of serotinin and norepinephrine in the synapse.

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: None

sections.title: Side Effects
sections.content: [Major]: GI, Sexual Effect.

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Selectively blocks SERT on the pre-synaptic neuron resulting in increased levels of serotonin in the synapse and increased activation of 5-HT1A receptors on post-synaptic neuron.

sections.title: Phenoxyphenylalkyl SAR
sections.content: [Basic nitrogen]: protonated at physiological pH; pKa 8.7−9.8. [Electron-withdrawing group]: para or meta substitution enhances binding affinity for SERT. [Phenoxy]: distinguishes antidepressant and antihistamine activity derived from diphenhydramine)

sections.title: Phenylalkyl SAR
sections.content: [Basic nitrogen]: protonated at physiological pH; pKa 9.5. [Chlorine]: enhances SERT selectivity.

sections.title: Side Effects
sections.content: [Major]: GI, Sexual Effect.

sections.title: MOA
sections.content: Blocks SET and NET on pre-synaptic neuron resulting in increased levels of serotonin and norepinephrine in the synapse. Some also acts as antagonists at 5HT2, Alpha1-adrenergic, histamine and muscarinic receptors.

sections.title: SAR Explained
sections.content: [Linker of 3 carbons]: between tricyclic ring system and basic nitrogen. Branching from linker decreases binding affinity for SERT and NET. Unsaturation of linker is tolerated. [R→ CH3]: tertiary amine imparts selectivity for SERT. [R’→ Cl or CN (EWG)]: enhances binding affinity for SERT. [Y→ can be C or N]. [Conformationally rigid [6.7.6]-fused ring system]: 7 membered ring in the middle is not coplanar; results in twisted shape

sections.title: Side Effects
sections.content: [Major]: Weight gain, GI, Sexual Effect.

sections.title: Monoamine Theory
sections.content: Deficiency of 5-HT and NE transmission in the CNS

sections.title: Neurotrophic Theory
sections.content: Decrease of Brain Derived Neurotophic Factor (BDNF) resulting in reduced neuroplasticity, decreased number of spines and thus, decreased neurotransmission.

sections.title: Low serotonin
sections.content: Anxiety, panic, phobia

sections.title: Low norepinephrine
sections.content: Decreased concentration, decreased working memory, decreased information processing, fatigue.

sections.title: Low dopamine
sections.content: Cognitive slowing, hypersomnia, anhedonia

sections.title: 5-HT
sections.content: GI and Nausea, Sexual Effects (decreased libido, sexual dysfunction), Mild Restlessness, Headaches and Insomnia

sections.title: Adrenergic
sections.content: Agitation (awakening), small increases in blood pressure and heart rate

sections.title: Antihistamine H1
sections.content: Sedation

sections.title: Alpha1-Adrenergic
sections.content: Hypotension

learnItems.title: Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Mechanism of Action
learnItems.question: Which compound below interferes with peptide cross-linking?
learnItems.explanation: Vancomycin (Compound 3) Binds directly to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminal to prevent peptide cross-linking.

learnItems.title: Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Mechanism of Action
learnItems.question: Which compound below inhibits the conversion of UDP-NAG→ UDP-NAM?
learnItems.explanation: Fosfomycin (Compound 2) Results in irreversible alkylation of the active cysteine on MurA.

learnItems.title: Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Mechanism of Action
learnItems.question: Which compound below inhibits Ala racemase & D-Ala ligase?
learnItems.explanation: Cycloserine (Compound 3) Prevents conversion of L-Ala→ D-Ala and the joining of D-Ala & D-Ala.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Mechanism of Action
learnItems.question: Which compound below inhibits pyrophosphatase?
learnItems.explanation: Bacitracin (Compound 1) Inhibits the recycling of bactoprene molecule.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: GT is diagnosed with C. difficile. Which oral antibiotic would be best to treat his infection?
learnItems.explanation: Vancomycin (Compound 3) is not orally absorbed, so it will stay in the gut to treat the infection in the large intestine

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: SM is diagnosed with a UTI infection. Which compound would be best to treat his infection and has few side effects?
learnItems.explanation: Fosfomycin (Compound 2) is indicated for urinary tract infections, and is especially active against E. Coli

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: GT has a history of psychosis. Which antibiotic below is best avoided in this patient?
learnItems.explanation: Cycloserine (Compound 1) acts as a partial agonist at the NMDA receptor can result in dose-dependent neurologic and psychiatric disturbances.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: BK has kidney dysfunction. Which 2 antibiotics below have side effects that would be harmful to this patient?
learnItems.explanation: Bacitracin (Compound 1) and vancomycin (Compound 3) can both result in nephrotoxicity.

learnItems.title: SAR Practice Problem
learnItems.name: Clinical Case Study
learnItems.question: AM’s bacterial infection is not responding to treatment. The bacteria in her body have become resistant to the antibiotic by producing D-Ala-D-Lac. Which of the antibiotics was she taking?
learnItems.explanation: Vancomycin (Compound 3) normally binds to D-Ala-D-Ala of the pentapeptide tail, but with this change to D-Ala-D-Lac, it can no longer bind.

testItems.question: Gram positive bacteria have ___________ in their cell wall that determine its rigidity and __________ to regulate cation movement.
In Gram negative bacteria the area between the cytoplasmic membrane and thin layer of peptidoglycan is called the ___________.
Source of acetate in N-acetyl glucosamine (NAG) is _________.
__________ is an irreversible inhibitor of MurA and targets the enzyme UDP-NAG Transferase
Fosfomycin is indicated for ___________
_____________ is a reversible competitive inhibitor of Alanine racemase and D-Ala D-Ala ligase
A serious side effect of cycloserine is ____________ caused by NMDA binding
_________ binds to pyrophosphatase and prevents regeneration of _________
Vancomycin binds to peptidoglycan to prevent crosslinking. Resistance to Vancomycin occurs through a change in structure of peptidoglycan from an ___________.
Vancomycin is not orally absorbed but can treat ___________
To avoid the side effect ___________, vancomycin should be infused _________
Daptomycin cannot be used for ________ because of inactivation by surfactants

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: PEP mimic, Reactive epoxide group

sections.title: Type of Inhibitor
sections.content: Irreversible inhibitor/Suicide inhibitor

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: MOA: Inhibits PEP which inhibits cell peptidoglycan synthesis - specifically NAM synthesis (Stage 1: Synthesis of Building Blocks) Bactericidal Target: UDP-NAG phosphoenoylpyruvuyl (PEP) transferase = MurA

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: 1) Mutation of active site (Microbe has Cysteine instead of Asp) 2) Mutation of glycerophosphate transporter

sections.title: Spectrum
sections.content: Broad – both Gram positive and Gram negative

sections.title: Toxicities
sections.content: Low Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, hypersensitivity, skin rash

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: D-Ala analogue, 5-membered ring

sections.title: Type of Inhibitor
sections.content: Non-covalent/competitive inhibitor – substrate mimic Binds 100x more tightly to the enzymes (rigid structure)

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: MOA; Competitive inhibitor of racemase Which inhibits cell peptidoglycan synthesis. (Stage 1: Synthesis of Building Blocks) Bactericidal Target: D-Ala-D-Ala racemase and D-Ala-D-Ala ligase

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: Overexpression of  D-alanine racemase (AlrA)

sections.title: Spectrum
sections.content: Broad – both Gram positive and Gram negative

sections.title: Toxicities
sections.content: Neurotoxic CNS disturbance, anxiety, confusion and drowsiness

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: Large molecule with many peptide bonds

sections.title: Type of Inhibitor
sections.content: N/A

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: MOA: Binds to pyrophosphatase in the presence of Magnesium,thus preventing regeneration of Bactoprene. It is more active if zinc is already present in the preparation, aiding in the binding to pyrophosphatase which inhibits cell peptidoglycan synthesis. (Stage 2: Synthesis of Membrane-bound Precursors and Polymerization) Bactericidal Target: Pyrophosphatases

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: Failure to penetrate membrane

sections.title: Spectrum
sections.content: Gram positive only – too big to get through outer membrane of Gram negative

sections.title: Toxicities
sections.content: Nephrotoxicity – not used systemically*/topical

sections.title: SAR
sections.content: Large molecule with many peptide bonds - Circled atoms form hydrogen bonds with D-Ala-D-Ala

sections.title: Type of Inhibitor
sections.content: Competitive/Reversible

sections.title: MOA & Target
sections.content: (Stage 2: Synthesis of Membrane-bound Precursors and Polymerization) Binds directly to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminal to prevent peptide cross-linking Bactericidal Target:  D-Ala-D-Ala

sections.title: MOR
sections.content: 1. Alter the substrate – make D-Ala-D-Lac. Results in loss of H-bond between vancomycin and dipeptide. 2.  Thicker cell wall of bacterium

sections.title: Spectrum
sections.content: Gram positive only

sections.title: Toxicities
sections.content: Redman syndrome (if infused too quickly), Nephrotoxicity, Hearing loss, Rash

learnItems.title: SAR Requirements
learnItems.name: Penicillin: Hover over compound to view areas.

compoundHotspots.name: β-Lactam Ring
compoundHotspots.text: β-Lactam Ring & Fused Bicyclic System: Creates a strained system (but less strain than the penicillins, so less reactive)

compoundHotspots.name: Position 1
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a nitrogen

compoundHotspots.name: Position 2
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a carboxylic acid for activity; binds to charged nitrogen of a lysine residue in the binding site

compoundHotspots.name: Position 3
compoundHotspots.text: Any change will lower activity

compoundHotspots.name: Position 4
compoundHotspots.text: Sulfur is usual, but not essential

compoundHotspots.name: Position 5
compoundHotspots.text: No substitutions allowed; cis stereochemistry with hydrogens at position 5 & 6 is essential

compoundHotspots.name: R Group
compoundHotspots.text: EWG: increases the acid stability of the compound. Bulky group: directly attached to the amide will make the compound more B-lactamase resistant. Polar group: broadens the spectrum as this allows the compound to pass through the porins of gram negative bacteria

compoundHotspots.name: Position 7
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a carbonyl

learnItems.title: SAR Requirements
learnItems.name: Cephalosporin: Hover over compound to view areas.

compoundHotspots.name: β-Lactam Ring
compoundHotspots.text: β-Lactam Ring & Fused Bicyclic System: Creates a strained system (but less strain than the penicillins, so less reactive)

compoundHotspots.name: Position 1
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a nitrogen

compoundHotspots.name: Position 2
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a carboxylic acid for activity; binds to charged nitrogen of a lysine residue in the binding site

compoundHotspots.name: Position 3
compoundHotspots.text: R2 Group: Non-metabolized group: increases oral activity & acid stability. MTT group: extended spectrum, longer-half life, higher potency. Pyrimidine ring (positive charge): forms a zwitterion & increases solubility. 1,3 thiazole ring: Anti-MRSA activity

compoundHotspots.name: Position 5
compoundHotspots.text: Sulfur is usual, but not essential

compoundHotspots.name: Position 6
compoundHotspots.text: No substitutions allowed

compoundHotspots.name: R1 Group
compoundHotspots.text: EWG: increases the acid stability of the compound. Bulky group: directly attached to the amide will make the compound more B-lactamase resistant. Polar group: broadens the spectrum as this allows the compound to pass through the porins of gram negative bacteria. Oxime: increases B-lactamase resistance.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 7
compoundHotspots.text: R3 group: Addition of OCH3 (7-alpha-methoxy) increases B-lactamase resistance

compoundHotspots.name: Position 8
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a carbonyl

compoundHotspots.text: Info: Specific requirements for Ceftaroline (5th generation) to be aware of

testItems.question: Penicillins bind and inhibit __________ to prevent crosslinking.
Resistance to penicillins develops quickly due to ________ or PBP mutations
Clavulanic acid, Sulbactam, and Tazobactam are all examples of β-lactamase ________.
_________ is combined with imipenem to avoid degradation in the kidney.
Carbapenem resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) can be treated with polymixin and ______.
Carbapenems cannot be combined with _________.
Cephalosporins are inherently ____ active than Penicillins but are ____ resistant to β-lactamases.
Cephalosporins substituted with a _______ can extend the spectrum but also cause side effects such as _______ and Disulfiram-like effect.
_______ are mostly reserved for serious Gram-negative infections such as meningitis.
_______ is an inhalent to treat chronic pseudomonas infections with CF patients, has activity against pseudomonas because it has the same side chain as _______.
